definitions: containing substances necessary for growth, health, and good physical condition
examples: The soup was both delicious and nourishing after her illness
Growing children need plenty of nourishing meals throughout the day

definitions: harmful, poisonous, or very unpleasant to smell or taste
examples: The factory released noxious fumes into the surrounding air
Some household chemicals produce noxious vapors when mixed together

definitions: relating to an unspecified term in a mathematical series or sequence
being the last or most extreme in a long series
examples: Calculate the sum of the nth term in the sequence
The mathematician derived a formula for the nth power
This is the nth time I've asked you to clean your room
She reviewed the document for the nth time before submitting

definitions: wearing no clothes, having the body completely uncovered or exposed
having a pale beige or pinkish-beige color resembling human skin tone
examples: The nude model posed for the art students' drawing class
Ancient Greek athletes competed nude in the Olympic games
She chose nude heels to match her evening dress perfectly
The decorator selected nude curtains for the minimalist bedroom design

definitions: made legally null and void, having no legal force or effect
made of no use or value, canceled out or rendered ineffective
examples: The court nullified the contract due to fraudulent misrepresentation
The election results were nullified after evidence of tampering emerged
His efforts were nullified by poor planning and lack of resources
The team's advantage was nullified when their star player got injured

definitions: deprived of the power of sensation, unable to feel touch or pain
unable to think, feel, or respond normally due to emotional shock
examples: Her fingers went numb from the freezing cold winter air
The dentist waited until my mouth was completely numb before drilling
He felt emotionally numb after hearing the devastating news
The tragedy left the community numb with grief and disbelief

definitions: marked with or distinguished by numbers in sequence or for identification
limited in number or quantity, suggesting something will soon end
examples: Each seat in the stadium was clearly numbered for easy location
The numbered tickets were distributed in order to waiting customers
His days at the company seemed numbered after the merger announcement
The endangered species has numbered days without immediate conservation efforts

definitions: causing a loss of physical sensation or feeling in body parts
so intense, boring, or repetitive as to make one mentally unresponsive
examples: The numbing cold made it difficult to grip the steering wheel
She applied a numbing cream before getting her tattoo done
The lecture was so numbing that half the students fell asleep
Working on the assembly line had a numbing effect on creativity

definitions: of, relating to, or denoting a number or system of counting
examples: Roman numeral symbols are still used on clock faces today
The ancient civilization developed a complex numeral system for mathematics

definitions: expressed as or relating to numbers rather than letters or words
examples: Please enter a numeric password using only digits zero through nine
The database requires numeric values for all financial data fields

definitions: of, relating to, or expressed as a number or numbers
examples: The report showed a clear numerical advantage in market share
Students must demonstrate strong numerical skills to pass the exam

definitions: of or relating to marriage or the wedding ceremony and celebration
examples: The couple exchanged their nuptial vows in a beautiful garden ceremony
They signed the nuptial agreement before their wedding day

definitions: cared for with attention, especially when sick, injured, or recovering
maintained or harbored in the mind over a prolonged period
examples: The injured bird was nursed back to health by wildlife volunteers
She nursed her broken ankle for several weeks before returning to work
He nursed a grudge against his former business partner for years
The team nursed hopes of making the playoffs until the final game

definitions: providing nourishment essential for growth and the maintenance of life
examples: The soil was rich in nutrient content perfect for growing vegetables
Leafy greens are nutrient dense foods packed with vitamins and minerals

definitions: relating to the process of providing or obtaining food necessary for health
examples: The nutritional value of processed foods is often lower than fresh
Parents should understand the nutritional needs of growing children

definitions: containing many of the substances needed for life and growth
examples: Fresh fruits and vegetables are highly nutritious food choices
The school cafeteria now serves more nutritious meals to students

definitions: crazy, mad, or extremely foolish in an informal sense
extremely enthusiastic about or fond of something or someone
examples: That stunt was absolutely nuts but somehow it worked perfectly
You'd have to be nuts to go swimming in this weather
She's nuts about classical music and attends every local concert
The kids are nuts about their new puppy

definitions: containing nuts or having the flavor or smell of nuts
silly, eccentric, or slightly mad in behavior or character
examples: The cake had a delicious nutty flavor from the almond extract
This cheese has a rich, nutty taste that pairs well with wine
His nutty sense of humor always makes the office meetings more fun
That's a pretty nutty idea but it might actually work

definitions: complying or willing to comply with orders or requests; submissive to authority
examples: The obedient dog sat patiently waiting for its owner's command
Good students are obedient to classroom rules and teacher instructions

definitions: grossly fat or overweight, typically with a body mass index over 30
examples: The doctor warned that obese patients face higher health risks
Nearly one-third of adults in some countries are classified as obese

definitions: arousing distaste or opposition; unpleasant, offensive, or open to objection
examples: Many parents found the movie's content objectionable for young children
The committee removed all objectionable language from the final report

definitions: restricted to a particular function, mode of life, or habitat by nature
examples: Certain bacteria are obligate parasites that cannot survive outside hosts
The obligate carnivore requires meat to meet its nutritional needs

definitions: bound or compelled legally, morally, or by social convention to do something
examples: She felt obligated to attend her cousin's wedding despite the distance
Tenants are obligated to pay rent on the first of each month

definitions: required by a legal, moral, or other rule; compulsory rather than optional
examples: Wearing seatbelts is obligatory for all passengers in the vehicle
The obligatory background check must be completed before employment begins

definitions: feeling gratitude toward someone for a service or favor they provided
legally or morally bound to do something; having an obligation
examples: I'm much obliged for your help with moving the furniture yesterday
We're obliged to you for your generous donation to our cause
All citizens are obliged to pay taxes according to the law
The contract obliged him to complete the work within thirty days

definitions: willing to do a service or kindness; helpful in a friendly way
examples: The obliging neighbor always offers to water plants during vacations
Staff at the hotel were particularly obliging with our special requests

definitions: neither parallel nor at a right angle; slanting in direction or position
not explicit or direct in addressing a point; deliberately indirect or evasive
examples: The oblique rays of the setting sun cast long shadows across the field
Draw an oblique line from the top corner to the opposite edge
His oblique reference to the scandal confused many audience members
She gave an oblique answer that avoided the real question entirely

definitions: having the power to destroy utterly or wipe out completely
examples: The bomb had obliterate force that could level entire city blocks
Time has an obliterate effect on even the strongest monuments

definitions: destroyed utterly; wiped out completely leaving no trace behind
extremely drunk or under the influence of drugs to the point of unconsciousness
examples: The ancient city was obliterated by the volcanic eruption centuries ago
The hurricane obliterated entire neighborhoods along the coastal region
He got completely obliterated at the party and couldn't remember anything
The students were obliterated after drinking all night

definitions: not aware of or not concerned about what is happening around oneself
examples: She was oblivious to the chaos happening behind her back
The child remained oblivious to his parents' financial struggles

definitions: having an elongated shape, longer than it is wide like a stretched rectangle
examples: The oblong table could seat twelve people comfortably for dinner
She arranged the flowers in an oblong vase on the mantel

definitions: extremely unpleasant, offensive, or annoying in behavior, manner, or appearance
examples: His obnoxious behavior at the restaurant embarrassed everyone at the table
The obnoxious smell from the garbage made it impossible to concentrate

definitions: offensive or disgusting by accepted standards of morality and decency
so large an amount or size as to be very shocking or unfair
examples: The movie was rated R for obscene language and graphic content
The vandals spray-painted obscene graffiti on the school walls
They paid an obscene amount of money for that tiny apartment
The CEO's obscene salary was 300 times the average worker's pay

definitions: not discovered or known about; uncertain, unclear, or hidden from view
not important or well known; remote from centers of activity
examples: The sign was obscure behind overgrown bushes and hard to find
Fog made the mountain path obscure and dangerous to navigate
She enjoys reading obscure poets from the nineteenth century
The researcher found the data in an obscure scientific journal

definitions: able to be noticed or perceived; discernible through observation or measurement
examples: The experiment produced observable changes in the plant's growth rate
There were no observable differences between the two paint samples

definitions: quick to notice things; alert and paying careful attention to details
adhering strictly to the rules of a particular religion or practice
examples: The observant detective noticed a tiny clue everyone else missed
Being observant while driving can prevent many potential accidents
The observant Jewish family keeps kosher and celebrates all holidays
She remained observant despite living far from her religious community

definitions: relating to or based on observation rather than experimentation or theory
examples: The study used observational methods to track animal behavior patterns
His observational skills made him an excellent wildlife photographer

definitions: noticed or perceived; seen, watched, or detected through careful attention
celebrated, kept, or solemnized according to custom, law, or practice
examples: The observed changes in temperature confirmed the climate model's predictions
Scientists observed unusual behavior in the test subjects after treatment
The observed holidays vary greatly between different cultures and religions
Traditionally observed customs were passed down through generations

definitions: watching carefully with attention to detail; engaged in observation
following, obeying, or keeping a law, custom, or practice
examples: The students spent hours observing insects in their natural habitat
She stood quietly observing the crowd's reaction to the announcement
The company is observing all safety regulations required by law
Many families are still observing ancient traditions passed down through generations

definitions: preoccupied with or constantly thinking about something to an unreasonable degree
examples: She became obsessed with finding the perfect wedding dress
The detective was obsessed with solving the cold case

definitions: of the nature of an obsession; causing someone to think about something constantly
examples: His obsessive attention to detail made him a perfectionist
The game has an obsessive quality that keeps players engaged for hours

definitions: becoming obsolete; going out of use or no longer serving a useful function
examples: Many obsolescent technologies are being replaced by smartphone apps
The factory still uses obsolescent machinery from the 1970s

definitions: no longer produced or used; out of date and replaced by something newer
examples: Typewriters have become obsolete in most modern offices
The software uses obsolete code that needs complete rewriting

definitions: of or relating to childbirth and the processes associated with it
examples: The hospital opened a new obstetric ward for expecting mothers
She specialized in obstetric nursing after completing her medical training

definitions: of or relating to the branch of medicine dealing with childbirth
examples: The obstetrical team prepared for the complicated delivery
Modern obstetrical practices have greatly reduced maternal mortality rates

definitions: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action
examples: The obstinate child refused to eat vegetables despite all persuasion attempts
His obstinate refusal to compromise led to the partnership's failure

definitions: blocked so as to prevent passage, progress, or clear view
examples: The obstructed airway required immediate medical attention to clear
Trees obstructed the view of the lake from the cabin

definitions: causing a blockage or obstacle; deliberately causing delays or difficulties
examples: The patient was diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea syndrome
His obstructive tactics prevented the committee from making any progress

definitions: able to be acquired, gotten, or procured through effort or purchase
examples: Fresh produce is easily obtainable at the local farmers' market
The rare book was only obtainable through specialized antique dealers

definitions: annoyingly insensitive or slow to understand something obvious to others
of an angle greater than 90 degrees but less than 180 degrees
examples: His obtuse remarks showed he completely missed the point of the discussion
Don't be obtuse - the answer is right in front of you
An obtuse angle is wider than a right angle in geometry
The triangle has one obtuse angle and two acute angles
